data.text:
Paula Cole Jones

“We Choose the Future: Beloved Community “

On Sunday, May 7th, we will commemorate the delivery of a sermon that was a turning point for Unitarians in the United States. The sermon delivered by William Ellery Channing on May 5, 1819 at the ordination of Rev. Jared Sparks, from the pulpit of the First Independent Church (now our First Unitarian Church of Baltimore), helped to define the future of a new Unitarian religion. Today, we are at another historic turning point as we give a new voice to the shared values and covenants that will help to define the future of Unitarian Universalism. How do the words of William Ellery Channing echo from 204 years ago to inspire us today?

Order of Service

Music and Service Notes

Paula Cole Jones, a lifelong Unitarian Universalist, innovator of institutional change, and founder of ADORE, A Dialogue on Race & Ethnicity, has been a leader in developing and advancing the 8th Principle and the Community of Communities as practices of the Beloved Community. Paula is the author of a UU World Magazine cover story, “Reconciliation as a Spiritual Discipline,” the editor of a Skinner House book, Encounters: Poems about Race, Ethnicity and Identity, and a contributing author to three other Skinner House books, including the UUA Common Read, Justice on Earth. Recently, Paula was awarded an honorary Doctorate of Divinity from Meadville Lombard Theological School. All Souls Church in Washington, DC, established the Paula Cole Jones Transformation Award and honored her as its inaugural recipient. She is also a member of the Article II Study Commission.

Adrian Graham, a member of our Baltimore church since 2003, has served our congregation as Trustee and Board Secretary as well as on the Adult RE Committee and the Ministerial Search Committee. He currently serves as Director of Congregational Engagement at the UU Congregation of Rockville and as a member of the UUA Commission on Appraisal.

Florence Beatrice Price (USA, 1887-1953), composer, organist, and pianist, was one of the first African-American women to gain prominence as a mainstream composer and performer. Born in Little Rock, Arkansas, she was a pupil of Chadwick and Converse at the New England Conservatory. She taught at Clark University and played her own piano concertos with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra

Rev. Dr. Natalie Fenimore is part of the ministerial team at The Unitarian Universalist Congregation at Shelter Rock in Manhasset, New York. Rev. Fenimore has been director of religious education, parish minister, and minister of religious education in Unitarian Universalist congregations in Maryland, Virginia, and New York since 1998. She is also past president of the Liberal Religious Educators Association.

Rev. Theresa I. Soto, author of Spilling the Light: Meditations on Hope and Resilience, is a Unitarian Universalist minister and activist. They have enjoyed interim ministry and chaplaincy with veterans. Soto lives in Oakland, CA with their partner, Rev. Sean Parker Dennison, and serves as a community minister with the First Unitarian Church of Oakland.

Rev. Gordon Stanley Light, ordained an Anglican priest in 1969, has served many parishes as well as in administrative positions (including bishop) in Canada. A founding member of The Common Cup Company, he is a singer and songwriter and plays acoustic guitar.

Mark A. Miller serves is Assistant Professor of Church Music at Drew Theological School and is a Lecturer in the Practice of Sacred Music at Yale University. He also is the Minister of Music of Christ Church in Summit, New Jersey. His dream is that the music he composes, performs, teaches and leads will inspire and empower people to create the beloved community. (COMPOSERS – Mark A. Miller (choristersguild.org)

Duke Ellington (1899-1974), a major figure in the history of jazz music, created one of the most distinctive ensemble sounds in Western music. Raised by two talented, musical parents in a middle-class neighborhood of Washington, D.C., he began studying piano at the age of seven, and earned the nickname “Duke” for his gentlemanly ways. Despite being awarded an art scholarship to the Pratt Institute in Brooklyn, Ellington followed his passion for ragtime and began to play professionally at age 17. In the 1920s, Ellington performed in Broadway nightclubs as a bandleader. He made hundreds of recordings with his bands, appeared in films and on radio, and toured Europe in the 1930s. Ellington’s fame rose to the rafters in the 1940s. His blend of melodies, rhythms and subtle sonic movements gave audiences a new experience—complex yet accessible jazz that made the heart swing. He earned 12 Grammy awards from 1959 to 2000, nine while he was alive. In 1958 he was presented to HM Queen Elizabeth II at a private reception, a meeting of such impact that he promised to compose a suite in her honor. Inspired by the beauty and majesty of nature, The Queen’s Suite remained hidden from the public until after his death when it received its premiere in 1998. (Adapted from: Biography.com

Harry Belafonte (1927-2023) was born to immigrant parents in Harlem, but spent much of his youth in his mother’s home country of Jamaica. After being honorably discharged from the Navy, he went back to New York, where he worked odd jobs until earning his first leading role at the American Negro Theatre. He made his film debut in 1953 and a year later won a Tony. At the same time, Belafonte developed his singing talents, having parlayed a series of nightclub performances into a record contract. His third album, Calypso, topped the charts for thirty-one consecutive weeks and was the first record to sell more than 1 million copies. Belafonte also secured a television outlet with his hour-long special, Tonight with Belafonte, which won him an Emmy. He became the first African American TV producer. Belafonte worked tirelessly to mobilize artists in support of the civil rights movement. In 1985, he again rallied the global artistic community to raise awareness of the famines, wars and droughts plaguing many African nations. USA for Africa raised more than $60 million with “We Are the World” and Hands Across America. He was a longtime anti-apartheid activist and maintained his commitment to service as a UNICEF goodwill ambassador.

Brad Montague is a writer and director on a mission to create meaningful things for kids and former kids. He is creator of the hit web series “Kid President”, author of the New York Times bestseller ‘Kid President’s Guide to Being Awesome’ and the upcoming ‘Becoming Better Grownups’. Kristi Montague is a designer, maker and jack-of-all-trades who owns and operates Montague Workshop, a creative studio, with her husband Brad.
